contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Gotti vincenzo ludovico 1.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Vincenzo Ludovico Gotti]] '''Vincenzo Ludovico Gotti''' (September 5, 1664 – September 18, 1742) was a [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal]] and [[theology|theologian]] of the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. Gotti was born in [[Bologna]]. Educated by [[Jesuit]]s, he entered the [[Dominican Order]] at the age of sixteen. After studies in [[Salamanca]] in [[Spain]], he was assigned to teach theology and philosophy at various schools of the [[Dominican Order]]. In 1688 Gotti was professor of philosophy at the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] College of Saint Thomas, the future [[Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas|Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, ''Angelicum'']].<ref>http://www2.fiu.edu/~mirandas/bios1728.htm Accessed 7-2-2011. http://books.google.com/books?id=fGYQAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA41#v=onepage&q&f=false Accessed 7-2-2011</ref> He also taught in [[Mantua]] and Bologna. In 1708, Gotti was elected [[Prior]] of the Dominican monastery in Bologna. On April 30, 1728, [[Pope Benedict XIII]] made him [[Cardinal Priest]] and appointed him [[Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem|Patriarch of Jerusalem]]. Together with [[Charles RenÃ© Billuart]], Gotti was the leading proponent of the [[Thomism|Thomistic school]] in his time. His writings include several polemics against [[Lutheran]]s and [[Calvinism]] as well as commentaries on [[Thomas Aquinas]]. Gotti was seen as a serious contender to be elected [[Pope]] at the [[Papal conclave, 1740|Papal conclave of 1740]], when [[Pope Benedict XIV|Cardinal Lambertini]] said to the [[College of Cardinals]] "If you wish to elect a saint, choose Gotti; a statesman, [[Pompeo Aldrovandi|Aldrovandi]]; an honest man, me".<ref>Michael J. Walsh, ''Pocket Dictionary of Popes'' (2006) [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vWP_K-lZCB0C&pg=PA21#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 21]</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{commonscat|Vincenzo Ludovico Gotti}} ==External links== *{{CathEncy|wstitle=Vincent Louis Gotti}} *MacCaffrey, J.: [http://catholicity.elcore.net/MacCaffrey/HCCRFR1_Chapter10.html ''History of the Catholic Church, Vol I, ch. 10'']; 1914.
